And then a block of 1.2 billion, of acquisitions of less than 100 million individually.

We'll give you all the details in the annexes and we're of course ready to supply you with additional information if you so require. We'll get back to you on that then, but I'll give the floor to someone else in the mean time. Yes please, over here.

Vincent de Blic from Cazenove. I have four questions, quick ones. The first on your dividend policy, you say that you confirm your dividend policy. To call a spade a spade, does that mean more than 10% in growth of earnings per share in 2009?
And you then gave us a contribution to EBITDA 2008 of CapEx 2008. Could you give us a contribution in 2011 of CapEx in 2008 and 2009 together?
No, I'm afraid I can't give you that. We'd like to, but I'm not sure that we can do that.

On WCR, which is perhaps a surprise for some of us, what improvement are you hoping for in 2009 on WCR? And about the tax rate, could you give us the guidance on 2008, because of the fall in profits is there likely to be a fall in taxation -- on the tax rate in 2009?

Working capital, first of all. Yes, on working capital there has been an increase of 3 billion in 2008, which of course is consistent with the increase in revenue and influenced by increases in volumes and prices. As business will be slowing, there shouldn't be an increase which is so high. There are a number of issues we shall also be turning around, the 700 million margin call which will be coming back.

And on the tax line, I said that we paid 800 million over the odds to various tax administrations in 2008. So that cash will be repaid to us in 2009. There is €1.5 billion coming back in, being repaid, plus the impact of the fall in revenues which will have an arithmetic impact on stocks and receivables.

The tax rate, will the tax rate fall? Will it fall because of the fall in revenues? Yes, the -- yes, clearly there will be a mechanical effect there. There are various impacts that you have to take into account, and I believe that looking at the trend, you should expect the tax rate to gradually converge on the normative tax rate of 33%.
Any other questions, please? Yes, over here.
Benjamin Leyre from Exane BNP Paribas. First question, what do you think about some governments' capacity to get money from the utilities? What do you feel about that?
We're against it.

Not surprised. What about your debate with the Belgian government on this? And do you think that you're going to benefit or lose from the replacement of the professional tax in France by something else? What you are going to propose to the Commission for regulated prices, and are you going to present a proposal?

And third point, could you tell us something about gas prices once again? What about the pricing formula which was validated by CRE, what will that mean in terms of a fall in prices in April? And what about return on capital, will that increase in 2009?

As far as governments and their attitude are concerned, we are against of course any approach which would be taking money out of the pockets of the utilities, certainly. As far as our discussions with the Belgian government are concerned, we've said very clearly that we were against this tax of 250 million, which was levied in 2008, which we paid in 2008, which is in our financial statements. We will be appealing against that and that will be done very quickly. We'll be appealing against that and taking the case to the Belgian Constitutional Court, the Belgian government knows that.

So we will be doing that for two reasons. The first is the tax is disproportionately high, 250 million, out of a series of businesses in Belgium, which have been considerably reduced by the divestment of Distrigas, the intercommunal gas, Fluxys, and so on so forth. And market shares that we've divested to E.ON or exchanged with E.ON and SPE. And then there's the anti-constitutional nature of the tax, which concerns one single tax payer. So it's anti-constitutional on those grounds. We are saying we're the only tax payer against which this tax is being levied, so we're going to fight that.

On the French professional tax, it's a little early to say what the impact on that is likely to be. We're very much in favor of that tax being removed. And surely, we will benefit from that. We have not yet heard of what is likely to replace it. There have been a few rumors flying around, but nothing very precise at this stage. So we really don't know. We pay our professional tax, 270 million I think last year, 270 million. The basically broken down more or less half about 50/50 between former businesses of GDF and former businesses of SUEZ. So that's basically the figure for us.
What about the Commission on regulated prices, can we say anything about that? You gave evidence to the Commission can you say anything on that?

No, I really don't know what the outcome's going to be. That's the main point. I think we will wait with a great deal of interest to see what the proposals are and whether they are accepted politically. What we're saying, of course, as you can imagine, is that we want the opening of the market. We want a market in France which is open, fully open for electricity. We don't think it is fully open yet. And we shall try and convince the MPs that this doesn't, of course, mean that electricity prices are going to soar as far as consumers are concerned.

What we have been saying for, say 2012, is that we would like to have a situation in which about 30% of the market is a market for alternative power producers. And that's basically what our rate, our percentage is in France. And we would like to be able to supply those power producers in a price which is compatible with market prices, so that there can be real competition. So there are various things can be done then, auction sales for instance, we are very happy with that.

And another thing that I'd like to say, a major point that we've been making, is that the new regulatory framework and the pricing framework must also aim to make it possible to build power producing, power generating assets in France, including EPRs. So that's something too that that the Commission will of course have on its agenda.

We've given evidence to the Commission. We've been very open-minded about our views. There are -- the technical side of things I think has been very well received, we shall have to see what happens politically.

As far as the fall in gas prices are concerned. I really can't give you a figure. If I were to give you a figure today that would simply complicate matters in terms of negotiating with the government. So I can't really say what we want. What we want above all, is to revert to a mechanism in which the raw material prices are at the same level as the non-raw material prices. The non-raw material prices are just as important to us as the raw material prices. And when prices go up, we are told you just consider yourself lucky to pass on some of your commodities costs and we'll see about non-commodity costs later on.

Well, no, we'd like to make sure that all our costs are properly included in the price formula, that's the law by the way. So all we have to do is to ensure that the law is properly enforced. And the fall in prices should take into account not only the fall in raw material prices which represent about 50% of the price paid by the consumer. But also changes in non-material costs -- non-raw material costs.

Well, I've been told that in 30 seconds time the microphones are going to be cut off and the lights switched off. So let me simply answer on ROCE, we give no guidance on ROCE. So that's a quick answer.
I'm sorry we have to close this meeting now. Ladies and Gentlemen, thank you very much for being with us this morning. And I wish you a very pleasant day.
